title: Rotational inertia - narrow cone hanging from tip

content.question: A narrow cone of height <math alttext="h sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>h</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> hangs vertically from a pivot point located at the cone’s tip, as shown in the figure. The cone can be modeled as a thin rod with a linear mass density <math alttext="lambda equals beta y squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>λ</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>β</mi><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>, where <math alttext="beta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>β</mi></math> is a constant with appropriate units, <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math> is the distance from the pivot along the cone’s central axis, and <math alttext="y equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> at the pivot. What is the rotational inertia of the cone about the pivot?
